descriptions.description: New users adopting the software increase the total user base.
Users leaving the project decrease the total user base.
Positive project activities and outcomes build up the project's reputation.
Negative events or stagnation cause the project's reputation to decline.
Higher software quality and more features enhance the project's reputation.
A larger user base provides more feedback and visibility, influencing reputation.
Positive interactions and collaboration build a healthier community.
Conflict and burnout erode the health and cohesion of the community.
Developers leaving the project reduce the number of core developers.
New pull requests being submitted increase the stock of new pull requests.
Initiating a review moves a pull request from 'new' to 'under review'.
Starting a review increases the number of pull requests under review.
Merging or committing code removes a pull request from the review queue.
Merging pull requests adds new code and features to the source code.
Rejecting a pull request removes it from the 'under review' stock.
Fewer core developers increases the average delay for reviewing pull requests.
Longer review delays slow down the provision of feedback to contributors.
As new contributors gain skills, they move out of the 'new' stock.
New contributors gaining skills increases the pool of experienced contributors.
Promoting experienced contributors reduces their number in that stock.
Promoting experienced contributors increases the number of core developers.
A higher joining rate increases the number of new contributors.
More pull requests under review increase the demand for providing feedback.
Knowledge loss, such as from documentation rot, depletes implicit knowledge.
Developer turnover directly causes a loss of their unique, implicit knowledge.
A larger stock of implicit knowledge increases the potential for mentorship.
Effective mentorship accelerates the skill development of contributors.
Effective mentorship prepares and qualifies contributors for promotion.
More core developers provide more capacity for mentorship and knowledge transfer.
Converting implicit knowledge into documentation adds to the implicit knowledge stock.
Converting implicit knowledge into documentation adds to the explicit knowledge stock.
Learning from documentation internalizes explicit knowledge, reducing its stock.
Learning from documentation internalizes knowledge, increasing implicit knowledge.
Timely feedback encourages new contributors to remain and stay engaged.
Constructive feedback helps experienced contributors improve and feel valued.
Positive feedback reinforces core developers' decisions and engagement.
More new contributors submitting PRs increases the demand for feedback.
More experienced contributors submitting PRs increases the demand for feedback.
Providing feedback is a necessary step before a PR can be merged or rejected.
Better documentation and guides make explicit knowledge more accessible for transfer.
Good documentation lowers the barrier to entry, increasing the joining rate.
Accessible documentation helps contributors learn and skill up faster.
Users and developers reporting bugs or features increase open issues.
Fixing issues reduces the number of open issues.
Fixing issues increases the number of closed issues.
More open issues represent more work, stimulating the creation of pull requests.
Community discussions and Q&A add valuable content to the knowledge base.
Feedback and discussions in PRs become searchable knowledge for future reference.
Resolved issues and their solutions are archived in the searchable knowledge base.
A growing knowledge base is a primary source for the project's explicit knowledge.
Forum discussions and chats contribute problem-solving insights to the knowledge base.
A strong project reputation attracts more potential contributors, increasing the joining rate.
A good reputation makes the software more attractive, potentially increasing the user base.
Open issues represent user needs and problems, generating feedback for the project.
User feedback often highlights new problems or features, creating more open issues.
More source code has a larger surface area for bugs, increasing issue creation.
A healthy, collaborative community is a positive signal that enhances project reputation.
A good reputation makes the project more attractive for new contributors to join.
Clear contributor guides make it easier for newcomers to join the project.
More maintainer time dedicated to issues increases the rate at which they are resolved.
A larger backlog of open issues can motivate or pressure the team to resolve them faster.
A high reputation sets high expectations; failing to meet them accelerates reputation decline.
A rich base of documentation provides the material for contributors to learn and internalize.
A larger user base means a larger pool from which users can churn due to dissatisfaction.
Pull requests that are successfully reviewed and approved are ready to be merged.
Pull requests that fail review or do not meet standards are rejected.
An accumulation of new pull requests creates a queue that needs to be reviewed.
Core developers may experience burnout, leading to their turnover.
Experienced contributors who demonstrate skill become candidates for promotion.
New contributors actively learning and participating increase their skill level.
A larger body of implicit knowledge is more susceptible to being lost over time.
A rich base of implicit knowledge provides more material to be documented and converted.
An unhealthy community is more prone to conflict and attrition, accelerating culture erosion.
